Articles.Content: It never really specifies what the unit is for fuel, but since everything else is in base metric system, may I assume its liters?
Arbitrary Fuel Units. Liters or some other volumetric units are a "good enough" approximation, though you get somewhat silly densities.
Each unit is 5 kg for most propellents.

*Most being fuel, air, and oxidizer

Monoprop is 4 kg/unit

Solid fuel is 7.5 kg/unit

Xenon is 0.1 kg/unit

Electricity is massless

You have a fairly common itch.

I'd be nicer if things were labeled.

=Smidge=
The wiki says litres, I think it says a density of 500kg/cubic metre. Which doesn't work too well for the 5kg/litre, I'll double check.
5kg/L so 5t/cubic metre. Pretty dense stuff (twice as dense as most earth rocks), but then again, what isn't in KSP.

It never really specifies what the unit is for fuel, but since everything else is in base metric system, may I assume its liters?

It's a reasonable enough assumption. But, if you use 1 fuel unit = 1 liter, you end up with fuel densities that are very high and the fraction of tanks actually occupied by fuel is very low. If you assume instead that 1 fuel unit = 5 liters, you get fuel densities that correspond more closely to real-life rocket fuels and the volume of fuel in the fuel tanks is much more sensible. I would guess that the devs used 1 unit = 5 liters when setting up fuel properties and tanks, but since they've never said so explicitly (as far as I know, and I don't think the wiki is definitive) it's only my guess. I like the name 'fuel cubit' for the unit of fuel, which I saw in a thread some time back.
